snippet.title: Geelong Cats superstar Patrick Dangerfield accepts one-match suspension and can't win Brownlow Medal
snippet.content:
Geelong superstar Patrick Dangerfield will not be eligible to win the 2017 Brownlow Medal after he accepted his one-match suspension from the match review panel. Dangerfield was sanctioned by the MRP for his tackle on Matthew Kreuzer, which drove the Carlton ruckman head-first into the Etihad Stadium turf and left him concussed.
Up Next
Nick Riewoldt announces retirement
01:42
More AFL Real Footy Videos
Previous slide Next slide
AFL plays of round 19
Fancy Hawthorn footwork, Gray's goal that devastated St Kilda, Geelong's Hawkins kicks a stunning six goals, Travis Cloke returns in style and the jaw-dropping draw in the dying seconds of Adelaide v Collingwood.
Kreuzer, who had no way of bracing himself as both of his arms were pinned, took no further part in the match on Saturday night. Dangerfield will miss the Cats' blockbuster clash with Sydney at Simonds Stadium on Friday night.
The former Crow's ineligibility makes Richmond star Dustin Martin the red-hot favourite for the AFL's most coveted individual award. AFL PLAYERS TO MISS OUT ON THE BROWNLOW MEDAL BECAUSE OF SUSPENSION
1996: North Melbourne ruckman Corey McKernan became the first player to miss out on the Brownlow because of a suspension. He served a one-match ban early in the season for kneeing Geelong's John Barnes to the back of the head. Without the ban, McKernan would have tied with Essendon's James Hird and the Brisbane Lions' Michael Voss. 1997: Western Bulldogs key forward Chris Grant polls one more vote than St Kilda's Robert Harvey. But Grant is ineligible for a controversial one-match striking ban - an open-handed slap on Hawthorn opponent Nick Holland.Photo: AAP 2012: Essendon's Jobe Watson wins the Brownlow, four votes ahead of Sam Mitchell (Hawthorn) and Trent Cotchin (Richmond). Four years later, the AFL strips Watson of the medal because of his doping ban, a consequence of the Essendon supplements debacle. In November last year, Mitchell and Cotchin were awarded their medals retrospectively at a special ceremony. It is understood Watson still has not handed back the medal to the AFL. RECENT BROWNLOW MEDALS WHERE INELIGIBLE PLAYERS HAVE GONE CLOSE 2006: Adam Goodes (Syd) 26, Daniel Kerr (WC) 22, third 2008: Adam Cooney (WB) 24, Goodes 21, fifth, Lance Franklin (Haw) 20, sixth 2011: Dane Swan (Coll) 34, Mitchell 30, second (Mitchell won several media awards that season) 2013: Gary Ablett (GC) 28, Steve Johnson (Geel) 25, fourth 2014: Matt Priddis (WC), 26, Nat Fyfe (Fre) 25, second THE CURIOUS CASE OF CHRIS JUDD Carlton star Chris Judd won his second Brownlow in 2010. In round 13, he had thrown his elbow back and collected Fremantle's Matthew Pavlich across the cheek, drawing blood. But the match review panel did not charge him. When asked about the incident on stage after receiving the medal, Judd smiled and said "yeah I was probably a bit lucky". The Brownlow is awarded to the AFL's best and fairest player, as voted by the umpires. A player who is guilty of an offence deemed worthy of a suspension becomes ineligible. New Brownlow favourite Dustin Martin has been fined twice this season - if he is fined again, he will be suspended and that will make him ineligible. With AAP
